captions.text:
Ms. Spalding:
Let me be patient

Though I may suffer
I'll envy it not

I can give away
everything I possess

But even without love
then I have no happiness

Now I know I'm imperfect
and not without sin
And I won't be too proud

See what we now know
is nothing compared
to the love that was shown when our lives were spared So...

Love him that nothing
compared to the life that

was shown when our
lives were spared

title: Esperanza Spalding Performs at the White House Poetry Jam:  (5 of 8)

comments.author: Stephanie Jimenez

comments.text:
Obama is doing well to craft a very tolerant and all-inclusive bunch of 
affairs I see. Is this meant to be an exercise in dissonant, 3rd world 
musical struggles with poor quality equipment? This performance sounds 
mangled. A large sum of the bass notes sound off. The thumb for this video 
is quite wild in essence, not something you'd imagine would come from the 
White House. If they are intent on increasing their diversity, why doesn't 
the White House invite someone with some talent... e.g. Kevin Keith or 
Tosin Abassi, not this poo. ﻿
comments.author: FunForAllTheFamily10

comments.text:
Lol tosin cant even play quarter notes in time. Hes got NO feel.  Although 
the shit he writes for AAL is badass. Nice use of polyrythms, odd times, 
etc And obviously matt gartska is a GENIUS.
comments.author: Paul Atreides

comments.text:
She is widely regarded as one of the finest young musicians on the planet. 
 She also plays bass for Joe Lovano, one of the world's most highly 
respected jazz saxophonists.  Kevin Keith plays some funky stuff on the 
chapman stick, but you need to get a clue on Esperanza.  Not everything has 
to have slap bass.  (To be fair, it is unusual to hear her struggle with 
intonation on the bass like she does here at times.)

comments.text:
Esperanza Spalding Performs at the White House Poetry Jam: (5 of 8) Born in 
1984, bassist, singer and composer Esperanza Spalding began playing in 
small jazz and blues venues around her hometown of Portland, Oregon. Soon 
after picking up the acoustic bass at the late age of 14, she helped form 
Noise for Pretend, an eclectic band fusing jazz and pop for which she sang 
and played bass (often simultaneously). The group signed with indie rock 
imprint Hush Records, which released two albums of their original 
compositions.﻿
comments.author: Ken Yoho (Cypherspace)

comments.text:
I think its fair to say that a) This piece is beautiful. An absolute work 
of art. b) It's absolutely fitting. The fact of the matter is that America 
was founded on a very potent and vigorous religion. Even though religion is 
indeed separate from state, it makes sense that the piece is there. c) 
People trolling are just looking for attention. They might get kicks out of 
feeling like they're above others or smarter than others by putting them 
down, but they honestly aren't work anyone's time :P

comments.text:
*Music Appreciation*

+Mike Shaw's music post today reminded me that I haven't posted any music 
content in a while (I don't count yesterday). To make up for it, I give you 
a woman with a ridiculous amount of talent, *before* she won a Grammy. 
Enjoy!

Don't forget to watch the video Mike posted, too. You will not regret it.
<https://plus.google.com/102518365620075109973/posts/Sv3V726p8pg>﻿

comments.text:
It's because so many have turned away from God, that so much hurt has 
ensued. We are a product of his love, so much love that we have the 
privilege of living and waking up every morning. His love and selflessness 
are what gives us the ability to have opinions and thoughts- even if they 
are not in his favor. God lives, in my heart and one day you too will look 
to him for compassion, help, forgiveness or strength, and guess what, he'll 
be right there waiting to hear you and everything you have to

comments.text:
She is incredible, beautiful voice and wonderful playing. Now aside from 
this, I could not care whether she sings about God or the guy down the 
street. It's music, and I think it's important to put it in perspective and 
enjoy this wonderful music for it's own sake, regardless of whether its 
biblical or not. Music doesn't need to have a message, it is it's own 
message, and music this beautiful speaks without words.
